title: Spain’s Supreme Court jails Catalan leaders for up to 13 years
text:
Protesters hold a banner reading "I accuse" in Barcelona on October 14 | Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images Spain’s Supreme Court jails Catalan leaders for up to 13 years They were convicted of sedition, disobedience and misuse of public funds but acquitted of the more serious charge of rebellion.

MADRID — Spain’s Supreme Court on Monday convicted 12 Catalan separatist leaders of sedition, disobedience and misuse of public funds and sentenced them to prison terms of up to 13 years for spearheading the region’s failed secession push in October 2017.

The ruling marks a decisive milestone after Spain’s gravest political crisis in four decades. Those convicted include most regional ministers at the time, the speaker of the regional parliament and the leaders of Catalonia’s two biggest pro-independence civic groups.

The court found Oriol Junqueras, the then-Catalan vice president and the highest-ranking official to face court, guilty of sedition and misuse of public funds. He faces the longest prison term among the accused — 13 years. He is also disqualified from public office for 13 years, starting from now.

The Supreme Court sentenced five of Junqueras' ministers to terms ranging from 10 to 12 years in prison, while it convicted three of them only of disobedience, which entails a fine and a disqualification from public office but no prison term.

The court sentenced Jordi Cuixart and Jordi Sànchez — the two civil leaders — to nine years in prison for sedition, and parliament Speaker Carme Forcadell to 11 years.

The panel of seven judges unanimously acquitted the accused of the more serious charge of rebellion — the penal code’s term for a "coup d’état" — which the public prosecutor had sought and can entail longer prison terms.

Most of those who were convicted were arrested and jailed on remand after they organized and carried out an illegal referendum on secession, explicitly disobeyed court orders and went ahead to declare independence on October 27, 2017 — which no country in the world recognized.

Carles Puigdemont, Catalonia’s president at the time of the events, fled the country to avoid detention after the declaration of independence and since then has fought extradition from a base in Belgium.

The Catalan government, which remains in the control of pro-independence parties, as well as secessionist civic organizations, called for public street protests in recent days in anticipation of the ruling. Thousands are expected to take to the streets on Monday and over the following days.

“We will be back stronger, more convinced and firmer than ever,” Junqueras said in a tweet posted on his official account, a message apparently sent from prison after the sentence was announced on Monday. “Thank you everyone because we will always persevere, always!”

The nearly 500-page ruling presents acting Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez with a difficult political challenge ahead of a repeat general election on November 10. The Socialist leader has warned he will defend constitutional order by all legal means necessary.
description: They were convicted of sedition, disobedience and misuse of public funds but acquitted of the more serious charge of rebellion.
